title: Binary logistic regression
description: Predicting palmetto species based on height, canopy width, canopy length, and leaf count
contents:
Introduction
The Environmental Data Initiative (EDI) provides datasets pertaining to Serenoa repens and Sabal etonia, the two dominant palemtto species at Florida’s Archbold Biological Station. This report utilizes data specific to survival, growth, and biomass estimates for the two palmetto species from 1981 - 2017. After initial expoloratory visualizations, a binary logistic regression is performed for several variables as predictors of palmetto species, followed by an evaluation of this model as a predictor tool.


Code

library(tidyverse)
library(kableExtra)
library(ggfortify)
library(viridis)
library(RColorBrewer)
library(hrbrthemes)
library(patchwork)
library(here)
library(tidyverse)
library(GGally) # for pairs plots
library(broom) # for tidy model outputs in dataframes
library(jtools) # to make quick graphs of model outputs

palmetto <- read_csv("palmetto.csv")



Section 1: Exploratory visualizations


Code

# according to metadata, 1 (in species column) refers to "Serenoa repens" and 2 refers to "Sabal etonia"
# see metadata for all other column/variable specifications

g_2 <-palmetto_explore <- palmetto %>% 
  select(species, height, length, width, green_lvs) %>% 
  mutate(species = as.factor(species))  # changing species classification from character to factor
  
g_1 <-palmetto_explore %>% 
  ggpairs(aes(color = species))

# pairs plots show lots of similarity in height and width, and the most visible difference in green leaves followed by length

# visualizing width and height by species
g_4 <-ggplot(data = palmetto_explore,
       aes(x = width,
           y = height)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species))
# appears to be lots of overlap between the species for height/width

# visualizing height and green leaves by species
g_5 <- ggplot(data = palmetto_explore,
       aes(x = height,
           y = green_lvs)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species))
# generally, nubmer of green leaves increases with height. species 1 appears to have a greater number of green leaves than species 2

# visualizing canopy length and green leaves by species
g_6 <- ggplot(data = palmetto_explore,
       aes(x = length,
           y = green_lvs)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species))
# generally, green leaves and canopy length appear to be positively correlated. species 1 tends to have more green leaves (and a broader range of # of leaves)
# 6215 of species 1, 6245 of species 2





Code

# Palmetto height by species density plot

graph_1 <- ggplot(data = palmetto_explore,
       aes(x = height, group = species, fill = species)) +
  geom_density(alpha = 0.5) +
  theme_ipsum() + # custom theme
  labs(x = "Height (cm)",
       y = "Density",
       title = "Palmetto height density distribution by species",
       caption = "Figure 1. Height density distriubtion of Serenoa repens and Sabal etonia") +
  theme(legend.position = c(0.9, 0.6), # moves legend
        legend.direction = "vertical",
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) + # legen orientation
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("#21908c80", "#fde72580"), # custom colors
                    name = "Species",
                    labels = c("Serenoa repens", "Sabal etonia"))

graph_1




Comparison of height density distribution of palmetto species shows significant overlap in density distribution. Generally, it appears that Sabal etonia tend to be slightly taller than Serenoa repens.


Code

# Palmetto width by species density plot

graph_2 <- ggplot(data = palmetto_explore,
       aes(x = width, group = species, fill = species)) +
  geom_density(alpha = 0.5) +
  theme_ipsum() + # custom theme
  labs(x = "Width (cm)",
       y = "Density",
       title = "Palmetto canopy width density distribution by species",
       caption = "Figure 2. Canopy width density distriubtion of Serenoa repens and Sabal etonia") +
  theme(legend.position = c(0.9, 0.6), # moves legend
        legend.direction = "vertical",
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) + # legen orientation
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("#21908c80", "#fde72580"), # custom colors
                    name = "Species",
                    labels = c("Serenoa repens", "Sabal etonia"))

graph_2




Comparison of canopy width density distribution by species shows significant overlap in distribution.


Code

# Palmetto canopy length by species density plot (length = widest length of the canopy)

graph_3 <- ggplot(data = palmetto_explore,
       aes(x = length, group = species, fill = species)) +
  geom_density(alpha = 0.5) +
  theme_ipsum() + # custom theme
  labs(x = "Canopy length (cm)",
       y = "Density",
       title = "Palmetto canopy length density distribution by species") +
  theme(legend.position = c(0.9, 0.6), # moves legend
        legend.direction = "vertical") + # legend orientation
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("#21908c80", "#fde72580"), # custom colors
                    name = "Species",
                    labels = c("Serenoa repens", "Sabal etonia"))





Code

# Palmetto leaf number by species density plot

graph_4 <- ggplot(data = palmetto_explore,
       aes(x = green_lvs, group = species, fill = species)) +
  geom_histogram(alpha = 0.5, bins = 19, color = "black") +
  theme_ipsum() + # custom theme
  labs(x = "Green leaf count",
       y = "Density",
       title = "Palmetto green leaf count density distribution by species",
       caption = "Figure 3. Green leaf count density distribution of Serenoa repens and Sabal etonia") +
  theme(legend.position = c(0.9, 0.6), # moves legend
        legend.direction = "vertical",
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) + # legen orientation
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("#21908c80", "#fde72580"), # custom colors
                    name = "Species",
                    labels = c("Serenoa repens", "Sabal etonia"))

graph_4




Histogram density comparison of green leaf count shows divergent trends between the two species. Broadly, it appears that Serenoa repens tends to have more green leaves than Sabal etonia.
Section 2: Binary logistic regression
In this section, a binary logistic regression is performed using plant height, canopy length, canopy width, and green leaf count as predictor values for species.


Code

# species has already been changed to a factor in palmetto_explore, so need to determine which factor is "0" level using levels(palmetto_explore$species)
# no need to use fact_drop() (see lab 3 part 1) because we're already working with just the species we need
# Species "1" (Serenoa repens) is 0 order, Species "2" (Sabal etonia) is 1 order

# setting up generalized linear model
dont_include <-palmetto_blr <- glm(species ~ height + length + width + green_lvs,
                    data = palmetto_explore,
                    family = "binomial")
# shows intercept/coefficient values for each predictor variable

dont_include_2 <- summary(palmetto_blr) # gives more information - all p-values are significantly < 0.05

# because species 1 is the reference species, the left-hand side of our log linear expression (equation) will the the probability of species 2 (the log odds of the non-zero level)
# we expect on average that as height increases, the odds of it being species 2 goes down (based on the sign), although it's the smallest coefficient of the 4.
# ... as length increases the odds of it being species 2 increase
# ... as width increases, the odds of it being species 2 decrese
# ... as number of green leaves increases, the odds of it being species 2 decrease. This is the largest coefficient of the 4, suggesting it may be the strongest predictor variable (this is also reflected in the graphs)





Code

# data viz - does it make sense that as number of leaves increases, the odds of being species 2 decreases?
g_3 <-ggplot(data = palmetto_explore,
       aes(x = species,
           y = length)) +
  geom_jitter(aes(color = species))





Code

# look at actual probabilities using broom::augment()
# What are the actual probabilities of being species 2 for each of the existing observations in our palmettoexplore dataframe?

g_9 <- palmetto_fitted <- palmetto_blr %>% 
  broom::augment(type.predict = "response")

# now added on to df we see more info for our model outcomes
# .fitted column is based on our blr, the probability based on 4 predictor variables, that our palmetto is species 2. 

# plotting fitted probabilities
graph_6 <- ggplot(data = palmetto_fitted,
       aes(x = green_lvs,
           y = .fitted)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species)) +
  geom_smooth(aes(color = species), se = FALSE) +
  labs(x = "Number of green leaves",
       y = "Probability of outcome Species 2")

# we see that there are plenty of species 1 that would be classified as species 2

# use broom::tidy() to convert to table

g_8 <-palmetto_table <- palmetto_blr %>% 
  broom::tidy() %>% 
  rename(coeficients = term) %>% 
  rename ("standard error" = std.error) %>% 
  rename("p-value" = p.value)


part_2_table <- palmetto_table %>% 
  kable(col.names = c("Coefficients",
                      "Estimate",
                      "Standard Error",
                      "Statistic",
                      "P-value")) %>% 
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = "striped", 
                full_width = F,
                position = "left") %>% 
    add_header_above(c("Table 1. Binary logistic regression results. Note that P-values are <<0.5, thus appearing as zero. Note that the reference species is Serenoa repens" = 5))

part_2_table




Table 1. Binary logistic regression results. Note that P-values are <<0.5, thus appearing as zero. Note that the reference species is Serenoa repens



Coefficients


Estimate


Standard Error


Statistic


P-value


(Intercept)


3.2266851


0.1420708


22.71180


0


height


-0.0292173


0.0023061


-12.66984


0


length


0.0458233


0.0018661


24.55600


0


width


0.0394434


0.0021000


18.78227


0


green_lvs


-1.9084747


0.0388634


-49.10728


0


Section 3: Model classification table


Code

palm_fit <- palmetto_fitted %>% 
mutate(species_name = case_when(species == 1 ~ "Serenoa_repens",
                             species == 2 ~ "Sabal_etonia"))

#palmetto_predict <- palmetto_fitted %>% 
 # broom::augment()


# palm_predict <- palm_fit %>% 
#   mutate(pred_spec = case_when(.fitted >= .5 ~ "Serenoa_repens",
#                                .fitted < .5 ~ "Sabal_etonia")) %>% 
#   mutate(true_pred = case_when(species_name == pred_spec ~ "Correct",
#                                species_name != pred_spec ~ "Incorrect"))
# 
# counting <- palm_predict %>% 
#   group_by(species_name) %>% 
#   count(true_pred)
# 
# count_table <- counting %>% 
#   pivot_wider(names_from = true_pred, values_from = n) %>% 
#   mutate(pct_correct = (Correct / (Correct + Incorrect))*100)

# trying again with switched species names
palm_predict_2 <- palm_fit %>% 
    mutate(pred_spec = case_when(.fitted >= .5 ~ "Sabal_etonia",
                               .fitted < .5 ~ "Serenoa_repens")) %>% 
  mutate(true_pred = case_when(species_name == pred_spec ~ "Correct",
                               species_name != pred_spec ~ "Incorrect"))

counting_2 <- palm_predict_2 %>% 
  group_by(species_name) %>% 
  count(true_pred)

count_table_2 <- counting_2 %>% 
  pivot_wider(names_from = true_pred, values_from = n) %>% 
  mutate(pct_correct = (Correct / (Correct + Incorrect))*100)

# make a kable table
library(kableExtra)

prediction_table <- count_table_2 %>% 
  kable(col.names = c("Species",
                      "Correctly Classified",
                      "Incorrectly Classified", 
                     "Percent Correctly Classified")) %>% 
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = "striped", 
                full_width = F,
                position = "left") %>% 
  add_header_above(c("Table 2. Prediction model outcome success counts and percentages" = 4))

prediction_table




Table 2. Prediction model outcome success counts and percentages



Species


Correctly Classified


Incorrectly Classified


Percent Correctly Classified


Sabal_etonia


5701


454


92.62388


Serenoa_repens


5548


564


90.77225


Conclusion
Some main takeaways from this report include:
Based on exploratory visualizations and coefficient values, green leaf count appears to be the best predictor variable for palmetto species, with more green leaves indicating a higher likelihood that the species is Serenoa repens.
The model created using binary logistic regression is a relatively good predictor of palmetto species, however, the model will still misclassify species on occasion.
References
Abrahamson, W.G. 2019. Survival, growth and biomass estimates of two dominant palmetto species of south-central Florida from 1981 - 2017, ongoing at 5-year intervals ver 1. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/f2f96ec76fbbd4b9db431c79a770c4d5

title: Time series visulizations
description: Willamette Falls fish passage time series summary (collaboration)
contents:
Overview
Summary: The Columbia River Data Access in Real Time (DART) program is part of the University of Washington’s Columbia Basin Research program. DART provides access to various environmental, riparian, and oceanic data, including salmonid-specific observations. This report utilizes DART data to explore adult fish passage from 2001 - 2010 at the Willamette Falls fish ladder on the Willamette River (Image 1). Included in the report are visualizations of various time series, seasonal patterns of fish observations, and annual fish species counts. 
Image 1: Willamette Falls Fish Ladder, circa 1913 Source: Old Oregon Photos


Image 2: Map of the Willamette Falls fish ladder. Source: US Army Corp of Engineers

Tab 1: Original time series


Code

# Time series- tsibble

willamette_ts <- willamette_long %>% 
   as_tsibble(key = fish_species, index = date) # not sure if key should be fish species or something else? 

ggplot (data = willamette_ts, aes(x = date, y = value))+
  geom_line()+
  labs(x = "Date", y = "Fish Count", title = "Fish counts at Willamette Falls (2001 - 2010)", subtitle = "Adult passage (fish/day)",
       caption = "Figure 1: Time series of Coho, Jack coho, and steelhead salmon passage from 2001 - 2010 (fish/ day)")+
  facet_wrap(~fish_species, nrow = 3, 
             labeller = labeller(fish_species =
                                   c("coho" = "Coho",
                                   "jack_coho" = "Jack Coho",
                                   "steelhead" = "Steehead")))+
  theme_classic()





There is a linear and seasonal trend for Coho. Between 2002 and 2010 the adult passage in fish per day for Coho has increased.
Jack Coho experiences a seasonal trend, but adult passage for Jack Coho is less successful than for Coho or Steelhead.
Steelhead experiences seasonal patterns
Tab 2: Seasonplots


Code

#Wrangle data for use in seasonplot
willamette_ts_season <- willamette_long %>% 
   as_tsibble(key = fish_species, index = date)

#Create color-blind friendly color palette (from r-cookbook)
cbPalette <- c("#999999", "#E69F00", "#56B4E9", "#009E73", "#F0E442", "#0072B2", "#D55E00", "#CC79A7", "#c71585", "#458b74")

#Create Seasonplot
willamette_ts_season %>% 
  gg_season(y = value) + 
  facet_wrap(~ fish_species,   #make a different plot for each fish species
             scales = "fixed") +   #fix the y axis 
  labs(title = "Seasonal Variation in Williamette Falls salmon passage",
       x = "Month",
       y = "Count",
       caption = "Figure 2: Coho, Jack coho, and steelhead salmon passage from 2001 - 2010 ",
       color = "Year") +  #label the legend
  theme_classic() +
  theme(legend.position = "right")





Coho salmon’s highest seasonal peak was in 2010.
Coho and jack-coho experience peaks in October, while Steelhead salmon experience peaks in June.
Steelhead salmon have a longer passage period than coho and jack-coho
Tab 3: Annual counts by species


Code

# summarize count by species and year
fish_year <- willamette_long %>% 
  mutate(year = year(date))  %>% # pulling just the year from the date
  replace_na() %>% 
  group_by(year, fish_species) %>% 
  summarize(annual_total = sum(value))
  
# graphing fish passage by species and year
ggplot(data = fish_year,
       aes(x = year,
           y = annual_total)) +
  geom_line(aes(color = fish_species)) +
  scale_x_continuous(expand = c(0,0),
                     breaks = seq(2001,2010,1)) +
  scale_y_continuous(expand = c(0,0)) +
  labs(x = "Year",
       y = "Annual observed",
       title = "Annual fish passage totals by species (2001-2010)",
       caption = "Figure 3: Annual fish passage totals for Coho, Jack Coho, and Steelhead  passage from 2001 - 2010 ",
      fill = "Fish species") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = -1)) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1, vjust = 0.5 )) +
  theme_classic() +
  scale_color_discrete(name = "Fish species", 
                       breaks = c("coho", "jack_coho", "steelhead"),
                       labels = c("Coho", "Jack Coho", "Steelhead")) 



Code

#scale_color_manual(values = cbPalette) 

# edited legend labels from http://www.cookbook-r.com/Graphs/Legends_(ggplot2)/



Summary statistics and analysis: major trends
Steelhead experienced a general decline in annual observed fish passage from 2001 -2009, with a sharp increase in passage in 2010. More data would be need to know if 2010 indicates a change in negative trend or if passage will generally continue to decline.
Coho and Jack Coho fish passage observations were signifantly lower than Steelhead from 2001 - 2008. In 2009, Coho passage increased sixfold to surpass Steelhead observations for that year, while Jack Coho counts stayed constant.
References
U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, NWD, Chelan, Douglas, Grant County PUDs, Yakima Klickitat Fisheries Project, Colville Tribes Fish & Wildlife (OBMEP), Oregon Department of Fish & Wildlife, Washington Department of Fish & Wildlife., Colombia Basin Research Data Access in Real Time., Retrieved from: (http://www.cbr.washington.edu/dart/query/adult_proj_sum)

title: Text wrangling and analysis
description: Word clouds and sentiment analysis for a silly youth magazine.
contents:
Introduction:
For this task I used an unsavory and perhaps sexist magazine I found on the (Internet Archive). I chose to perform a sentiment analysis on the 2009 edition of (Just for Girls and Guys Youth Magazine) by the Human Life Alliance. The first half (pages 1-8) is “just for girls”, while the second half (pages 9-16) is “just for boys”. The two halves are meant to give each side insight into the other gender. I wanted to see how the sentiments differed (if at all) between the “girls’” side and the “boys’” side.
Part 1: Word count visualization


Code

# girl-focused pages are 1-8. boy-focused pages are 9-16.
girl_top_50 <- nonstop_counts %>% 
  filter(page == c(1:8)) %>% 
  arrange(-n) %>% 
  slice(1:50)

boy_top_50 <- nonstop_counts %>% 
  filter(page == c(9:16)) %>% 
  arrange(-n) %>% 
  slice(1:50)

girl_cloud <- ggplot(data = girl_top_50,
                     aes(label = word)) +
  geom_text_wordcloud(aes(color = n, size = n)) +
  scale_size_area(max_size = 8) +
  labs(title = "50 most common words in Just for Girls") 


boy_cloud <- ggplot(data = boy_top_50,
                     aes(label = word)) +
  geom_text_wordcloud(aes(color = n, size = n)) +
  scale_size_area(max_size = 8) +
  labs(title = "50 most common words in Just for Boys") 





Code

girl_cloud




Figure 1: Word cloud for the 50 most common words in “Just for Girls”, pages 1-8. Word size is representative of frequency.


Code

boy_cloud




Figure 2: Word cloud for the 50 most common words in “Just for Boys”, pages 9-16. Word size is representative of frequency.
Part 2: Sentiment analysis


Code

# sentiment analysis using AFINN lexicon 
mag_afinn <- mag_nonstop_words %>%  # finding common words beteen mag_nonstop_words and afinn lexicon
  inner_join(get_sentiments("afinn"))

# for each page, how many times does each sentiment score show up?
afinn_counts <- mag_afinn %>% 
  count(page, value)

afinn_means <- mag_afinn %>% 
  group_by(page) %>% 
  summarize(mean_afinn = mean(value))

plot_2 <- ggplot(data = afinn_means,
       aes(x = page,
           y = mean_afinn)) +
  geom_col(aes(fill = mean_afinn)) +
  scale_fill_gradient(low = "deeppink",
  high = "dodgerblue2") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 8, linetype = "dashed", color = "darkgray") +
  labs(x = "Page number", y = "Score", title = "Mean AFINN score per page", fill = "Score range") +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal()

plot_2



Code

# girl-targeted pages are 1-8, boy-targeted pages are 9-16. it seems that in general, the boy-targeted pages are associated with a higher positivity than the girl-targeted pages



Figure 3: Sentiment analysis of Just for Girls and Boys Youth Magazine using the AFINN lexicon. Pages 1-8 are “Just for Girls” while pages 9-16 are “Just for Boys”.
References
Human Life Alliance. “Just for Girl and Guys Youth Magazine.” 2009: https://archive.org/details/j4g09/mode/2up

title: Working with raster data
description: Visualizing marine species richness in California
contents:
Introduction:
Aquamaps is a map-based tool which provides data and visualizations for the world’s marine species. Here, cetacean data for a portion of California is used to visualize marine species richness.


Code

# then plot

ggplot() +
  geom_raster(data = richness_df,
              aes(x = x, y = y, fill = layer)) +
  geom_sf(data = state, fill = "snow2") +
  coord_sf(xlim = c(-126, -114), ylim = c(31, 42)) + # defining coordinates
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(x = "longitude", y = "latitude",
       title = "Species richness of Cetaceans along California's coast",
       fill = "Species richness") +
  scale_fill_viridis_c(na.value = "white") 




Figure 1: Figure 1. Map of species richness of Cetaceans along the California coast. Richness is a measure of aggregate species presence as opposed to a single species. A threshold of 0.75 was chosen in order to observe greater detail in species richness patterns, while maintaining coverage for areas of lesser species richness .



References
Kaschner, K., K. Kesner-Reyes, C. Garilao, J. Segschneider, J. Rius-Barile, T. Rees, and R. Froese. 2019. AquaMaps: Predicted range maps for aquatic species. World wide web electronic publication, www.aquamaps.org, Version 10/2019.

title: Welcome to where you'd expect my blog to be.
contents:
Blogs I would write if I wrote blogs
Have you seen this?
How about this?
